title: Exploring Artistic Legacy: Analyzing Artifact Differences Across Kingdoms Using Machine Learning
text:
This research project is a new journey from Machine Learning to Kingdom Learning with Mathematics, Art and Data Science (MADS), exploring mathematical concepts embedded in historical paintings and their evolution across different kingdoms in Sri Lanka.
This project strongly aligns with the 2025 International Day of Mathematics theme: Mathematics, Art, and Creativity, emphasizing the importance of the intersection between mathematics and art.
Furthermore, this project closely aligns with the mission of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura—‘Develop globally competent citizens through our education for a sustainable future, drawing inspiration from our cultural heritage and wisdom.’ The principal investigator, Dr Thiyanga S. Talagala, is affiliated with the university and actively contributes to this vision.

Contact
Dr Thiyanga S. Talagala, Senior Lecturer, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura.

title: Motivation
text:
Sri Lanka has a rich history of blending mathematics and art, especially in its ancient architecture, wall paintings, frescoes and murals. The main goal of this project is to develop machine learning algorithms to uncover mathematical concepts rooted in historical paintings and artefacts of Sri Lanka.
Figures 1 to 5 show some Sri Lankan wall paintings and artefacts embedded with mathematical principles such as geometry, tessellation, symmetry, coloring algorithms, and motif. Clearly, these elements are not just artistic choices but are deeply rooted in mathematics. This further reinforces my belief: behind every mathematician there is an artist, and behind every artist there is a mathematician.

title: Results Already Achieved
section: Exploring the Evolution of Color Palettes in Ancient Wall Paintings Across Different Kingdoms Using Machine Learning
text:
Exploring the Evolution of Color Palettes in Ancient Wall Paintings Across Different Kingdoms Using Machine Learning
Thiyanga S. Talagala, Department of Statistics, Faculty of Applied Sciences, University of Sri Jayewardenepura
Sri Lanka is home to a rich cultural heritage, including vibrant ancient wall paintings. However, limited research has applied data science to analyze these artistic treasures. This study investigates variations in color palettes across different historical kingdoms using machine learning. Digital images of wall paintings were collected from Kandy, Dambulla, and Sigiriya. Hexadecimal color values were extracted from each image to quantify the dominant hues. A supervised machine learning algorithm was then trained to classify paintings based on their respective kingdoms using color patterns. The model demonstrated high accuracy in predicting the kingdoms. This research provides new insights into the artistic evolution of ancient wall paintings.

section: Methodology Used to Extract Hexadecimal Colour Values
text:
Methodology Used to Extract Hexadecimal Colour Values
The eyedroppeR in R was used to extract Hexadecimal colour values from the image. An reproducible code is here:

#devtools::install_github("doehm/eyedroppeR")
library(eyedroppeR)
path <- "img/example.jpg"
extract_pal(12, path, label = "Dambulla")
